Todd, I also agree with Jeff that HyperNEAT has some advantages beyond
just=
 working with geometric regularities.  Although we have
highlighted geometr=
ic regularity in our papers recently, another one
is the ability to increas=
e substrate density (i.e. the number of
neurons) holistically and still ret=
ain functionality, as we showed in
our publications from 2007:

http://eple=
x.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html#gauci.gecco07
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/public=
ations.html#dambrosio.gecco07

This ability allows a novel kind of complexi=
fication that can increase
complexity by orders of magnitude in an orderly =
way.   It is what
allowed us to produce a working network with 8 million ne=
urons in the
paper by Jason Gauci and myself.

There are some other advanta=
ges that we have not even pointed out yet,
such as an easy way to express a=
 "connectivity group," which means one
whole group of neurons connecting to=
 another partner group in an
orderly manner, similar to a "nerve" in the br=
ain.  It turns out that
such a group connection in the substrate can be exp=
ressed elegantly by
a CPPN.

However, I am not certain whether overall the =
advantages of HyperNEAT
apply to time series prediction.  Peter may be corr=
ect that this
domain is not necessarily the right one for HyperNEAT.  Yet I=
 would
still encourage you to try if you have a gut feeling about it, becau=
se
on the chance that HyperNEAT does provide some advantage, we will only
d=
iscover it by trying it out.  

It is even possible that time could be arra=
nged along one axis of the
substrate, thereby leveraging the "geometry of t=
ime" as an advantage.
 There may be something to that, i.e. the idea that t=
here is a
relationship among inputs that come from points in time that are =
close
together in terms of how they relate to what is coming next. 
HyperNE=
AT may be able to capture that geometry through some kind of
sliding window=
 of inputs arranged in temporal order.  Yet it would not
be a traditional w=
ay of processing a time series.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Todd Ow=
en" <jtoddowen@...> wrote:
>
> Jeff,
> 
> Your last post was how I wanted t=
o respond to Petar, but your
> explanation is much better.  From reading th=
e published papers, I
> can't find a penalty for using HyperNEAT even if NE=
AT by itself may
> suffice.  Am I correct here?
> 
> --Todd
> 
> --- In nea=
t@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > There are other bene=
fits to HyperNEAT that have nothing to do with
> geometry,
> > no? It is an=
 indirect encoding, and thus is more likely to create
> modular
> > phenoty=
pes that exhibit repetitions and symmetry (with and without
> > variation).=

> > 
> > Unless I am mistaken, these benefits can cause HyperNEAT to
> out=
perform NEAT
> > even on problems where geometry is not being exploited. Do=
es that
sound
> > right to everyone?
> > 
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > Jeff Clune
>=
 > 
> > Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> > 
> > jclune@
>=
 >
>
